Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Plant/pollinator networks in a rare, wet El Nino year
Award.AbstractNarration:
Long-term records documenting the effects of climate variability on ecological interactions among species are rare, but this type of information is critical to making accurate predictions of ecological consequences of climate change. Lacking long term data, an alternative approach is to examine shorter-term change in species interactions in response to rapid climate shifts, and combine that information with a detailed understanding of long-term climatic trends. This project extends a detailed study of pollinator abundance and species diversity (primarily bumblebees) with plant flowering patterns in coastal, central California. This region had been experiencing an increasingly severe drought, and average temperatures that have been increasing for decades. The current warm, wet El Nino event presents a unique opportunity to assess the responses and resilience of this system of pollinators and plant species. A diverse and abundant assemblage of pollinator species is critical to the maintenance of native plant species in this region. This study will inform the management of nature reserves and will also provide important information on how pollinators, which are essential to US agriculture, respond to climate change. The project will help broaden participation in science through graduate student training, and through a workshop to engage land managers of relevant habitats.

The work addresses three specific, testable hypotheses: (1) plant flowering and pollinator activity will be temporally disconnected in the wet El Nino year; (2) bumblebees respond immediately to the resource boom provided by heavy, extended flowering in the El Nino, but solitary bee responses will be delayed a year; and (3) pollinator networks will be more specialized in the wet El Nino year than during the drought, because bees will select more preferred plant species when flowers are abundant. The potential temporal mismatch is an important ecological problem in the context of changing climatic variability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant and pollinator interactions are sensitive to variations in rainfall. The intense, prolonged California drought (2012 – 2015) reduced the number of interactions and structure of plant/pollinator networks in grasslands and sandhills along the central California coast compared to historical surveys at the same sites. In particular, networks became less specialized in both habitats, and less compartmentalized in sandhills. The major questions we addressed in the current project were whether and how fast the plant and pollinator communities could recover from the drought once normal levels of rainfall returned. In particular, we assessed how univoltine vs multivoltine life histories recovered from the drought. We are currently still identifying some of the bees and plants that were sampled during this study, eventually enabling us to better compare communities in greater depth over time.

The main conclusion from the comparison of bees with different life histories is that the number of pollination events by both univoltine and multivoltine bees generally responded to rainfall the previous year. Their abundances were low following years of low rainfall – presumably reflecting reduced availability or plant resources – and high after years of better rain. This suggests that the abundance of multivoltine bees in spring is influenced by both the cumulative effects of the previous year’s rain as well as resources in the current year. For univoltine bees, only resources available in the previous year determine abundance in the current flowering season. However, habitat and local climate matter: in relatively mild grassland habitats, bee abundance was relatively constant over fairly broad differences in more rainfall and increased markedly only following a year of particularly high rain; in contrast, bee abundance was more sensitive to the full range of rainfall variation in the relatively stressful sandhill environment, with univariate bee species particularly hit hard by drought at those sites.

The results of our studies enable us to predict how plants and pollinators will respond to the more frequent and prolonged droughts expected in the coming decades. These predictions are particularly important in environmentally sensitive habitats such as the sandhills, which even with rainfall patterns during the past 30 years have been subject to conservation concerns because the many endemic and rare species have been impacted by both building and sand mining. Knowing the extent of these changes can help land managers better adapt conservation strategies to future climates.
